Hello Justin,


Am Dienstag,=
 25. M=E4rz 2003 13:32 schrieb uweanimal:
> Hi,
>
> I am trying to write so=
me test cases but I am not sure how to do it.
>
> I have a program which ta=
kes a XML input file and runs it through an
> XSLT process.
>
> What is the=
 best way to test that this has been achieved sucessfully?
Logically or phy=
sically (implementation)?
Logically, you could do this by:
a) Validation ag=
ainst DTD or Schema
b) asserting some XPath expressions

String comparisons=
 of course won't do:
"<img xmlns=3D'http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml' src=3D'..=
.' alt=3D'...'/>" and 
'<html:img alt=3D"..." src=3D"..." xmlns:html=3D"htt=
p://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" 
></htmlimg>' are unequal Strings but equal XML =
Elements.

String comparisons will only do if both the actual XML and expec=
ted XML String 
are canonical XML, and even then success is very limited:
-=
 - The indention and other whitespace considered ignorable might still diff=
er
- - The contents of processing instructions and maybe even comments that=
 are 
semantically identical might differ, e.g. <?xml-stylesheet type=3D"te=
xt/css" 
href=3D"bla.css"?> vs. <?xml-stylesheet href=3D"bla.css" type=3D"t=
ext/css"?>

So, don't use String comparisons. I'm sure you already figured =
that out.

> Any input on this subject or a link to a page which gives guid=
elines
> would be useful

There are several ways to achieve this.
When I ju=
st do a series of XSLT, I usually don't do this using a Java program, 
I us=
e the xslt/style task of Ant. Then I use the XmlValidate task to validate 
=
both - source before the transformation and destination files after the 
tr=
ansformation. Of course this can be only achieved if asserting validity 
ag=
ainst a DTD (or, if you patch the XmlValidate Task, a Schema) is 
sufficien=
t.

For more, you might want to take a look at:

* http://xmlunit.sourcefor=
ge.net/
This package provides an assertXMLEquals method that compares two s=
trings, 
taking XML equality into account, so <br></br> and <br /> are cons=
idered 
equal.

* http://httpunit.sourceforge.net/
This is more powerful, b=
ut less XML-specific. It's especially then extremely 
useful if you want to=
 do HTTP based tests.

* http://xsltunit.org/
A completely different approa=
ch not based on JUnit is this Unit testing 
framework proof of concept for =
XSLT. I really like this approach.

Depending on the task you need to solve=
 (only assert structure or also assert 
contents), a combination might be u=
seful.
Usually for XSLT specific stuff I use validation, a perl program for=
 
generating a file list in XML and my own XSLT stylesheet which is taking =
that 
file list and performing unit tests against all these files.

The big=
gest advantage of JUnit based unit testing is the brand report 
generation =
using JUnitReport (automation is usually achieved with Ant 
anyway).

Most =
powerful would be a set of methods like assertXPath, though there are 
some=
 stumbling blocks:
- - One method for each XPath type or one for all of the=
m?
- - There's no official XPath Framework for Java yet (as far as I know),=
 only 
implementations, so either use DOM and be slightly incompatible with=
 XPath, 
or use XPath and settle on a specific library like Xerces/Xalan, d=
epending on 
all changes of that library.
